article.title: Dachshund

template.arg: Teckel ([[Benelux|BNL]]/[[France|FR]]/[[Germany|GER]]), Dackel ([[Germany|GER]]), Dash it hound ([[Philadelphia]]), Tekkel ([[Benelux|BNL]]), Tekkel Doxie ([[United States|US]]ba), Weenie Dog ([[United States|US]]) (S.A.), Wiener Dog/Hotdog ([[United States|US]]), Sausage Dog ([[United Kingdom|UK]]/[[United States|US]]/[[Australia|AUS]]/[[South Africa|ZA]]), Bassotto ([[Italy|I]]), Sosis ([[Turkey|TR]]), Perro Salchicha ([[Spain|ES]]/[[Mexico|MX]]), Worshond ([[South Africa|RSA]]), Taksis ([[Latvia|LV]]), Jamnik ([[Poland|PL]]), Train kukka(Andhra pradesh(india)), Badger Dog (literal translation)

article.paragraph: Thedachshund(IPAc-enUKˈdæksəndorIPAc-enUSˈdɑːkshʊntRespellDAHKShuuntorIPAc-enUSˈdɑːksənt;cite webhttp://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/dachshund?showDachshund - Definition and More from the Free Merriam-Webster DictionaryMerriam-webster.com2012-05-16) is a short-legged, long-bodieddog breedbelonging to thehoundfamily. The standard size dachshund has been developed toMacrosmaticscent,huntingchase, and flush outbadgersand otherburrow-dwelling animals, while the miniature dachshund has been bred to hunt smaller prey such asrabbits. In theAmerican Westthey have also been used to huntprairie dogs. Today, they are also bred forconformation showsand as family pets. Some dachshunds participate inearthdog trials. According to the AKC, the dachshund remains one of the top 10 dog breeds in the United States of America.cite webAKC Dog Registration Statisticshttp://www.akc.org/news/the-most-popular-dog-breeds-in-america/American Kennel Club12 January 2013
article.heading: Etymology
article.paragraph: File:Smooth Dachshund red and tan portrait.jpgthumbA short haired dachshundFile:Jamnik dugowosy standardowy LM 671.jpgthumbrightA standard long-haired dachshundFile:MiniDachshund1 wb.jpgthumbA black and tan miniature dachshundThe name "dachshund" is ofGerman languageGermanword originoriginand literally means "badger dog", fromDachs("badger") andHund("hound, dog"). The pronunciation varies widely inEnglish languageEnglish: variations of the first and secondsyllablesincludeIPAc-enˈdɑːks-,IPAc-enˈdæks-andIPAc-en-hʊnt,IPAc-en-hʊnd,IPAc-en-ənd. Although "dachshund" is a German word, in modern German they are more commonly known by the nameDackelor, among hunters,Teckel. The German word is pronouncedIPA-deˈdakshʊnt.cite webDachshundDudenhttp://www.duden.de/rechtschreibung/Dachshund2012-11-25
Because of their long, narrow build, they are often nicknamedwiener dogorsausage dog.
article.heading: Classification
article.paragraph: While classified in the hound group or scent hound group in the United States and Great Britain, there are some who consider this classification to be arguable, speculating that it arose from the fact that the wordHundis similar to the English wordhound. Many dachshunds, especially the wire-haired subtype, may exhibit behavior and appearance that are similar to that of theterriergroup of dogs.cite bookNicholasAnnaDachshundTFH PublicationsNeptune City19870-86622-158-110An argument can be made for the scent (or hound) group classification because the breed was developed to use scent to trail and hunt animals, and probably descended from scent hounds, such asbloodhounds, pointers,Basset Hounds, or evenBruno Jura Hounds; but with the persistent personality and love for digging that probably developed from the terrier, it can also be argued that they could belong in theterrier, or "earth dog", group.In theFdration Cynologique Internationale(World Canine Federation), or FCI, the dachshund is actually in its own group, Group 4, which is the dachshund group.cite webFédération Cynologique Internationale Group 4 "Dachshund Group"http://old.fci.be/nomenclatures_detail.asp?langFédération Cynologique Internationale2009-06-16Part of the controversy is because the dachshund is the only certifiable breed of dog to hunt both above and below ground.cite webAmerican Kennel Club Dachshund Breed Informationhttp://www.akc.org/breeds/dachshund/American Kennel Club2009-06-16
article.heading: Characteristics
Appearance
article.paragraph: File:Dachshund.jpgthumbA wire-haired dachshundA typical dachshund is long-bodied and muscular, with short, stubby legs. Its front paws are unusually large and paddle-shaped, for extreme digging. Long coated dachshunds have a silky coat and short featherings on legs and ears. It has skin that is loose enough not to tear while tunneling in tight burrows to chase prey. The dachshund has a deep chest that provides increased lung capacity for stamina when hunting prey underground. Itssnoutis long with an increased nose area that absorbs odors.cite webA Brief History of the Breedhttp://www.almosthomerescue.org/about_dach/history.htmAlmostHomeRescue.org2009-06-16
article.heading: Coat and color
article.paragraph: Dachshunds exhibit three coat varieties: smooth coat (short hair), long hair, and wire-hair.Wirehaired is the least common coat in the US (it is the most common in Germany) and the most recent coat to appear in breeding standards.

Dachshunds have a wide variety of colors and patterns. They can be single-colored, single-colored with spots ("dappled"-called "Merle (coat colour in dogs)merle" in other dog breeds), and single-colored with tan points plus any pattern. Dachshunds in the same litter may be born in different coat colors. Dachshunds also come inpiebald. The dominant color is red, the most common along with black and tan. Two-colored dogs can be black, wild boar, chocolate, fawn, with tan "points", or markings over the eyes, ears, paws, and tail, of tan or cream. A two-colored dachshund would be called by its dominant color first followed by the point color, such as "black and tan" or "chocolate and cream". Other patterns include piebald, in which a white pattern is imposed upon the base color or any other pattern, and a lighter "boar" red.cite webhttp://www.dachshund.org/Colors/breed_colors_patterns.htmlDachshund Colors and PatternsThe Dachshund Magazine OnlineJuly 2, 2007http://web.archive.org/web/20070407182354/http://www.dachshund.org/Colors/breed_colors_patterns.htmlApril 7, 2007The reds range from coppers to deep rusts, with or without somewhat common black hairs peppered along the back, face and ear edges, lending much character and an almost burnished appearance; this is referred to among breeders and enthusiasts as a "stag" or an "overlay" or "sable". True sable is a dachshund with each single hair banded with three colors: light at the base of the hair, red in the middle, black at the end. An additional striking coat marking is the brindle pattern. "Brindle" refers to dark stripes over a solid backgroundusually red. If a dachshund is brindled on a dark coat and has tan points, it will have brindling on the tan points only. Even one single, lone stripe of brindle is a brindle. If a dachshund has one single spot of dapple, it is a dapple.

Solid black and solid chocolate dachshunds occur, and even though dogs with such coloration are often considered handsome, the colors are nonstandard, that is, the dogs are frowned upon in the conformation ring in the US and Canada. Chocolate is commonly confused with dilute red. Additionally, according to the conformation judges of the Dachshund Club of America (DCA) and theAmerican Kennel Club(AKC) the piebald pattern is nonstandard. However, the piebald dachshund can still be shown. The only disqualifying fault in Dachshunds is knuckling over. While some judges choose to dismiss a dog of color, many choose to judge them and those who are actually judging the dog will look past the cosmetic color of a dog and judge the conformation of the dog first. There were several piebald dachshunds that became AKC Champions in 2008. All things being equal between the dogs in the ring, the traditional colors which are listed in the Official AKC Standard (governed by DCA) should be visibly listed.

Dogs that are double-dappled have the merle pattern of a dapple, but with distinct white patches that occur when the dapple gene expresses itself twice in the same area of the coat. The DCA excluded the wording "double-dapple" from the standard in 2007 and now strictly use the wording "dapple" as the double dapple gene is commonly responsible for blindness and deafness.

Breeders may also breed a piebald dapple brindle; and although dogs with this coloring are increasingly popular due to their unique markings, they are not considered standard and are not allowed to show.

tablerow.tablecell:
Std Dachshund 600.jpgthumbcenter
A long-haired standard dachshund

article.heading: Size
article.paragraph: File:Dachshund5.jpgthumbShort haired dachshundImage:Parti-colour Longhaired Dachshund.jpgthumbrightA parti dapple longhaired dachshundImage:Silver Dapple Smooth Haired Miniature Dachshund.jpgthumbBlack and tan dapple smooth-haired miniature dachshund with one blue eye and one brown eyeDachshunds come in three sizes: standard, miniature,cite webhttp://www.akc.org/dog-breeds/dachshund/#standardDachshund Breed StandardAmerican Kennel Club2009-02-03andkaninchen(German for "rabbit"). Although the standard and miniature sizes are recognized almost universally, the rabbit size is not recognized by clubs in the United States and the United Kingdom, but is recognized by all of the clubs within theFdration Cynologique InternationaleFdration Cynologique Internationale (World Canine Federation)(FCI), which contain kennel clubs from 83 countries all over the world.cite webFédération Cynologique Internationale Official Websitehttp://www.fci.be/default.aspxFédération Cynologique Internationale2009-06-16An increasingly common size for family pets falls between the miniature and the standard size, frequently referred to as "tweenies," not an official classification.cite webhttp://dogtime.com/dog-breeds/dachshundDachshunddogtime.com14 April 2014better sourceApril 2014

A full-grown standard dachshund averagesconvert16lbontoconvert32lbon, while the miniature variety normally weighs less thanconvert12lbon.The kaninchen weighsconvert8lbontoconvert11lbon. According to kennel club standards, the miniature (and kaninchen, where recognized) differs from the full-size only by size and weight, thus offspring from miniature parents must never weigh more than the miniature standard to be considered a miniature as well.While many kennel club size divisions use weight for classification, such as the American Kennel Club, other kennel club standards determine the difference between the miniature and standard by chest circumference; some kennel clubs, such as in Germany, even measure chest circumference in addition to height and weight.cite bookFor the Love of DachshundsHutchinsonRobert2005BrownTrout Publishers1-56313-903-0112http://books.google.com/?id2009-06-16

H. L. Menckensaid that "A dachshund is a half-dog high and a dog-and-a-half long,"cite webQuote Daddyhttp://www.quotesdaddy.com/quote/609465/Henry+Louis+Mencken/dachshund-a-half-a-dog-high-and-a-dog-and-a-half2009-06-16although they have been referred to as "two dogs long".cite webDachshund PoetryQuotesDaddy.comhttp://members.tripod.com/~mcox_2/type.html2009-06-16This characteristic has led them to be quite a recognizable breed, and they are featured in many a joke and cartoon, particularlyThe Far SidebyGary Larson.cite bookLarsonGaryWiener Dog Art: A Far Side CollectionAndrews McMeel Publishing19900-8362-1865-5
article.heading: Eye color
article.paragraph: File:Red piebald dox miniature long hair.jpgthumbnailRed piebald long hair miniature dachshund puppyLight-colored dachshunds can sport amber, light brown, or green eyes; however, kennel club standards state that the darker the eye color, the better. They can also have eyes of two different colors; however, this is only found in dapple and double dapple dachshunds.cite webhttp://www.dachshund.org/article_double_dapple.htmlThe Double DappleThe Dachshund Magazine OnlineJune 25, 2007Dachshunds can have a blue and a brown eye. Blue eyes, partially blue eyes, or a blue eye and a brown eye are called "wall" coloring, and are considered a non-desirable trait in kennel club standards. Dappled eyes are also possible.
Wall-eyeis permissible according to DCA standards. Piebald-patterned dachshunds will never have blue in their eyes, unless the dapple pattern is present.
article.heading: Temperament
article.paragraph: Dachshunds are playful, but as hunting dogs can be quite stubborn,cite webDachshundhttp://www.akc.org/dog-breeds/dachshund/#standard2012-11-26and are known for their propensity for chasing small animals, birds, and tennis balls with great determination and ferocity.cite bookStallSamThe Good, the Bad, and the Furry93–94Quirk Books20051-59474-021-6cite bookKilcommonsBrianBrian KilcommonsWilsonSarahPaws to Consider156–1570-446-52151-5cite webDachshund infohttp://www.albertadachshundrescue.com/dachshundinfo.cfm2009-07-25Many dachshunds are stubborn, making them a challenge to train.cite webIs a Dachshund Right For Youhttp://www.wienerdogrescue.com/index.php?optionWienerDogRescue.com2009-07-25cite webFrequently Asked Questionshttp://www.dachshundrescue.org/faq.htmlDachshundRescue.org2009-07-25cite webDachshund Factshttp://www.3doxies.com/archives/2011/04/08/dachshund-facts/3doxies.com2011-04-08

template.arg: Being the owner of dachshunds, to me a book on dog discipline becomes a volume of inspired humor. Every sentence is a riot. Some day, if I ever get a chance, I shall write a book, or warning, on the character and temperament of the dachshund and why he can't be trained and shouldn't be. I would rather train a striped zebra to balance an Indian club than induce a dachshund to heed my slightest command. When I address Fred I never have to raise either my voice or my hopes. He even disobeys me when I instruct him in something he wants to do.

article.paragraph: Dachshunds are statistically more aggressive to both strangers and other dogs.cite journalhttp://www.appliedanimalbehaviour.com/article/S0168-1591(08)00114-7/abstractBreed Differences in Canine Aggression10.1016/j.applanim.2008.04.006Applied Animal Behavior ScienceDuffy, Deborah2008etalDespite this, they are rated in the intelligence of dogs as an average working dog with a persistent ability to follow trained commands 50% of the time or more.cite bookCorenStanleyThe intelligence of dogs2006Free press0-7432-8087-3They rank 49th inStanley Coren'sThe Intelligence of DogsIntelligence of Dogs, being of average working and obedience intelligence.They can have a loud bark. Some bark quite a lot and may need training to stop, while others will not bark much at all.Dachshunds are known for their devotion and loyalty to their owners,cite webPhysical Characteristics and Temperamenthttp://www.dachshund-dca.org/faq.html#temperamentDachshund Club of America2009-07-25though they can be standoffish towards strangers.If left alone, many dachshunds will whine until they have companionship. Like many dogs if left alone too frequently, some dachshunds are prone toSeparation anxiety in dogsseparation anxietyand may chew objects in the house to relieve stress.
Dachshunds are burrowers by nature and are likely to burrow in blankets and other items around the house, when bored or tired.

Dachshunds can be difficult to housebreak, and patience and consistency is often needed in this endeavor.cite webThings You Need To Know about Adopting a Dachshund!http://www.dachshund-dca.org/faq.html#faqNebraska Dachshund Rescue2009-11-19

According to the American Kennel Club's breed standards, "the dachshund is clever, lively and courageous to the point of rashness, persevering in above and below ground work, with all the senses well-developed. Any display of shyness is a serious fault."cite webhttp://www.akc.org/dog-breeds/dachshund/#standardDachshund Breed StandardAmerican Kennel ClubMay 14, 2007Their temperament and body language give the impression that they do not know or care about their relatively small size. Like many small hunting dogs, they will challenge a larger dog. Indulged dachshunds may become snappy or extremely obstinate.cite webhttp://www.burkesbackyard.com.au/1999/archives/25/roadtests/dog_breeds/dachshundsDachshundsBurke's Backyard with Don BurkeMay 14, 2007

Many dachshunds do not like unfamiliar people, and many will growl or bark at them.cite webDisposition and temperamenthttp://www.dachworld.com/dispositiontemperament.htmDachworld.com2009-07-26Although the dachshund is generally an energetic dog, some are sedate. This dog's behavior is such that it is not the dog for everyone. A bored, untrained dachshund will become destructive.If raised improperly and not socialized at a young age, dachshunds can become aggressive or fearful.They require a caring, loving owner who understands their need for entertainment and exercise.File:Double Dapple Dachshund.jpgthumbleftDouble dapple dachshund puppy sleepingDachshunds may not be the best pets for small children. Like any dog, dachshunds need a proper introduction at a young age. Well trained dachshunds and well behaved children usually get along fine. Otherwise, they may be aggressive and bite an unfamiliar child, especially one that moves quickly around them or teases them.However, many dachshunds are very tolerant and loyal to children within their family, but these children should be mindful of the vulnerability of the breed's back.

A 2008University of Pennsylvaniastudy of 6,000 dog owners who were interviewed indicated that dogs of smaller breeds were more likely to be "genetically predisposed towards aggressive behaviour". Dachshunds were rated the most aggressive, with 20% having bitten strangers, as well as high rates of attacks on other dogs and their owners. The study noted that attacks by small dogs were unlikely to cause serious injuries and because of this were probably under-reported.cite newsLevyAndrewhttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-1032531/Why-sausage-dogs-really-just-legged-fiends.htmlWhy Sausage dogs are really just four-legged fiendsDaily Mail, UK2008-07-072009-11-19Londoncite newsDobsonRogerhttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/howaboutthat/2254479/Sausage-dogs-are-the-most-aggressive-dogs.htmlSausage dogs are the most aggressive dogsDaily Telegraph, UK2008-07-082009-11-19London
article.heading: Health
article.paragraph: The breed is known to have spinal problems, especiallyDegenerative disc diseaseintervertebral disk disease(IVDD), due in part to an extremely longvertebral columnspinal columnand short rib cage.cite journalV. F.JensenA. K.Ersbøll2000Mechanical Factors affecting the Occurrence of Intervertebral Disc Calcification in the Dachshund – a Population StudyJournal of Veterinary MedicineA475283–29610.1046/j.1439-0442.2000.00296.xThe risk of injury may be worsened byObesity in petsobesity, jumping, rough handling, or intense exercise, which place greater strain on thevertebrae. About 2025% of Dachshunds will develop IVDD.cite webhttp://www.ufaw.org.uk/intervertebraldicdiseasedachshunds.php Intervertebral Disc DiseaseGenetic Welfare Problems of Companion AnimalsUniversities Federation for Animal Welfareufaw.org.uk10 February 2015

Treatment consists of combinations of crate confinement and courses of anti-inflammatory medications (steroids and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs like carprofen and meloxicam), or chronic pain medications, liketramadol. Serious cases may require surgery to remove the troublesome disk contents.cite journal10.1111/j.1532-950X.1999.00421.xBVScDhupaMPHNDavidJ. Waters DVMPhDDiplomate ACVS-1#SaritNita Glickman MS1999Reoperative Neurosurgery in Dogs With Thoracolumbar Disc DiseaseVeterinary Surgery286421–42810582738A dog may need the aid of a cart to get around if paralysis occurs.File:Kennel Assoc. Dog Show.jpgthumbleftShort-haired dachshundA new minimally invasive procedure called "percutaneous laser disk ablation" has been developed at theOklahoma State UniversityStillwaterOklahoma State University Veterinary Hospital.cite webhttp://www.vetmedpub.com/vetmed/On+the+Forefront/On-the-Forefront-Prophylactic-laser-disk-ablation-/ArticleStandard/Article/detail/440886?contextCategoryIdOn the Forefront: Prophylactic laser disk ablation in dogs at Oklahoma State University – Veterinary Medicine2007-07-012009-11-19Originally, the procedurecite journalKenneth E.BartelsHigbeeRussell G.Robert J.BahrDavid S.GallowayTiffany S.HealeyChristopherArnoldhttp://avmajournals.avma.org/doi/abs/10.2460/javma.2003.222.1733Outcome of and complications associated with prophylactic percutaneous laser disk ablation in dogs with thoracolumbar disk disease: 277 cases (1992–2001)June 15, 2003222121733–1739Journal of the American Veterinary Medical Association10.2460/javma.2003.222.1733was used in clinical trialsonly on dachshunds that had suffered previous back incidents. Since dachshunds are prone to back issues, the goal is to expand this treatment to dogs in a normal population.

In addition to back problems, the breed is also prone toluxating patellapatellar luxationwhich is where the kneecap can become dislodged.cite bookCoileD. CarolineEarle-BridgesMichelleThe Dachshund HandbookBarron's Educational Series20051260-7641-2673-3Dachshunds may also be affected byOsteogenesis imperfecta(brittle bone disease). The condition seems to be mainly limited to wire-haired Dachshunds, with 17% being carriers.Cite journalEckardtJ.KluthS.DierksC.PhilippU.DistlO.Population screening for the mutation associated with osteogenesis imperfecta in dachshunds10.1136/vr.101122Veterinary Record17214364201323315765A genetic test is available to allow breeders to avoid breeding carriers to carriers. In such pairings, each puppy will have a 25% chance of being affected.cite web"Brittle Bone" Gene in Dachshunds Discoveredhttp://www.dachshund-dca.org/Media/newsletter%20articles/2011%20Articles/BrittleBoneGeneVaccinations.pdfNewsletterDachshund Club of America6 April 2013

In some double dapples, there are varying degrees of vision and hearing loss, including reduced or absent eyes.cite webParizoAngiehttp://www.starlightkennel.com/Dapple.htmlDouble Dapple Warnings2009-11-19Not all double dapples have problems with their eyes and/or ears, which may include degrees of hearing loss, full deafness, malformed ears, congenital eye defects, reduced or absent eyes, partial or full blindness, or varying degrees of both vision and hearing problems; but heightened problems can occur due to the genetic process in which two dapple genes cross, particularly in certain breeding lines. Dapple genes, which are dominant genes, are considered "dilution" genes, meaning whatever color the dog would have originally carried is lightened, or diluted, randomly; two dominant "dilution" genes can cancel each other out, or "cross", removing all color and producing a white recessive gene, essentially a white mutation.cite webhttp://www.weatherlysdachshunds.com/genes.htmlRecessive and Dominant GenesWeatherly's Miniature Dachshunds2009-11-19When this happens genetically within the eyes or ears, this white mutation can be lethal to their development, causing hearing or vision problems.

Other dachshund health problems include hereditaryepilepsy,cite bookAdamsonEveDachshunds for DummiesFor Dummies20072nd2310-470-22968-3granulomatous meningoencephalitis, dental issues,Cushing's syndrome,thyroidand autoimmune problems,cite webhttp://www.ufaw.org.uk/IMMUNEMEDIATEDTHROMBOCYTOPENIADACHSHUNDS.php Immune-Mediated ThrombocytopeniaGenetic Welfare Problems of Companion AnimalsUniversities Federation for Animal Welfareufaw.org.uk10 February 2015variousallergyallergiescite bookAdamsonEveDachshunds for DummiesFor Dummies20072nd2320-470-22968-3andatopyatopies, and various eye conditions includingcataracts,glaucoma,progressive retinal atrophy,corneal ulcers, nonucerative corneal disease,sudden acquired retinal degeneration, andcherry eye. Dachshunds are also 2.5 times more likely than other breeds of dogs to developpatent ductus arteriosus, a congenital heart defect. Dilute color dogs (Blue, Isabella, and Cream) are very susceptible toCanine follicular dysplasia#Color dilution alopeciaColor Dilution Alopecia, a skin disorder that can result in hair loss and extreme sensitivity to sun. Since the occurrence and severity of these health problems is largely hereditary, breeders are working to eliminate these.
article.heading: History

link.part: Old-style dachshund showing the longer legs

article.paragraph: File:Deiker Jagdbare Tiere 1093210.jpgthumbIllustration of dachshund baying aEuropean badgerSome writers and dachshund expertscite bookShieldsGeorge O.The American Book of the DogLoefflerWilliamDachshunds217–239http://books.google.com/?idCassell and CoUniversity of California1891have theorized that the early roots of the dachshund go back toancient Egypt, where engravings were made featuring short-legged hunting dogs.M. Zedda, P. Manca, V. Chisu, S. Gadau, G. Lepore, A. Genovese, V. Farina (2006) "Ancient Pompeian Dogs Morphological and Morphometric Evidence for Different Canine Populations, Anatomia, Histologia, Embryologia",Journal of Veterinary MedicineSeries C 35 (5), 319-324.Recent discoveries by theAmerican University in Cairoofanimal mummiesmummifieddachshund-like dogs from ancient Egyptian burial urns may lend credibility to this theory.Citation neededOctober 2015In its modern incarnation, the dachshund is a creation of GermanDog breedingbreedersand includes elements ofGermanyGerman,FranceFrench, andEnglandEnglishhounds andterriers. Dachshunds have been kept by royal courts all over Europe, including that ofVictoria of the United KingdomQueen Victoria, who was particularly enamored of the breed.cite webDachshund History Queen Victoriahttp://smalldogbreedsinformation.com/dachshund/Dachshund History Sub Category2014-05-03They were originally bred for hunting badgers by trailing scent.

The first verifiable references to the dachshund, originally named the "Dachs Kriecher" ("badger crawler") or "Dachs Krieger" ("badger warrior"), came from books written in the early 18th century.Der vollkommene teutsche Jger (The Complete German Hunter), Johann Friedrich von Flemming, 17191724, Leipzig.Prior to that, there exist references to "badger dogs" and "hole dogs", but these likely refer to purposes rather than to specific breeds. The original German dachshunds were larger than the modern full-size variety, weighing betweenconvert30and40lbkgon, and originally came in straight-legged and crook-legged varieties (the modern dachshund is descended from the latter). Though the breed is famous for its use in exterminating badgers andbadger-baiting, dachshunds were also commonly used forrabbitandfoxhunting, for locating woundeddeer, and in packs were known to hunt game as large asWild Boarwild boarand as fierce as thewolverine.Citation neededMay 2013

There are huge differences of opinion as to when dachshunds were specifically bred for their purpose of badger hunting, as the American Kennel Club states the dachshund was bred in the 15th century, while the Dachshund Club of America states that foresters bred the dogs in the 18th or 19th century.

Double-dapple dachshunds, which are prone to eye disease, blindness, or hearing problems, are generally believed to have been introduced to the United States between 1879 and 1885.Citation neededJune 2009

The flap-down ears and famous curved tail of the dachshund have deliberately been bred into the dog. In the case of the ears, this is to keep grass seeds, dirt, and other matter from entering theear canal. The curved tail is dual-purposed: to be seen more easily in long grass and, in the case of burrowing dachshunds, to help haul the dog out if it becomes stuck in a burrow.The smooth-haired dachshund, the oldest style, may be a cross between theGerman Shorthaired Pointer, aPinscher, and a Bracke (a type ofbloodhound), or to have been produced by crossing a shortBruno Jura Houndwith a pinscher.cite webHistory and Developmenthttp://www.dachshund-dca.org/faq.html#developmentDachshund Club of America2009-06-16Others believe it was a cross from a miniature French pointer and a pinscher; others claim that it was developed from thebloodhoundSt. Hubert Hound, also a bloodhound, in the 18th century,cite webDachshund Dog Breed Originshttp://www.5stardog.com/dog-breeds-dachshund.asp5StarDog2009-06-16and still others believe that they were descended fromBasset Hounds, based upon their scent abilities and general appearance.

The exact origins of the dachshund are therefore unknown. According to William Loeffler, fromThe American Book of the Dog (1891), in the chapter on dachshunds: "The origin of the Dachshund is in doubt, our best authorities disagreeing as to the beginning of the breed."What can be agreed on, however, is that the short-haired dachshund gave rise to both the long-haired and the wire-haired varieties.

There are two theories about how the standard longhair dachshund came about. One theory is that smooth Dachshunds would occasionally produce puppies which had slightly longer hair than their parents. By selectively breeding these animals, breeders eventually produced a dog which consistently produced longhair offspring, and the longhair dachshund was born. Another theory is that the standard longhair dachshund was developed by breeding smooth dachshunds with various land and water spaniels. The long-haired dachshund may be a cross among any of the small dog breeds in the spaniel group, including theGerman SpanielGerman Stoberhund, and the smooth-haired dachshund.

The wire-haired dachshund, the last to develop, was bred in the late 19th century. There is a possibility the wire-haired dachshund was a cross between the smooth dachshund and various hard-coated terriers and wire-haired pinschers, such as theSchnauzer, theDandie Dinmont Terrier, theGerman Wirehaired Pointer, or perhaps theScottish Terrier.cite webDachshund Breed Resourceshttp://www.furrycritter.com/resources/dogs/Dachshund.htmFurryCritterNetwork2009-06-16
article.heading: Symbol of Germany

link.part: Waldi, the mascot of the1972 Summer Olympics1972 Summer Olympic Games

article.paragraph: Dachshunds have traditionally been viewed as a symbol of Germany.Political cartoonistscommonly used the image of the dachshund to ridiculeGermany.cite webPolitical Cartoon for War Bondshttp://dachshundlove.blogspot.com/search/label/historyThe New York TimesApril 5, 19432009-06-16DuringWorld War Ithe dachshunds' popularity in the United States plummeted because of this association. As a result, they were often called "liberty hounds" by their owners similar to "liberty cabbage" becoming a term for sauerkraut mostly in North America.cite bookA Sort of LifeGreenGraham49–49http://richardshepherd.net/2006/ClaudiasSunangel.htmlThe stigma of the association was revived to a lesser extent duringWorld War II, though it was comparatively short-lived. KaiserWilhelm IIand German Field MarshalErwin Rommelwere known for keeping dachshunds.

Due to the association of the breed with Germany, as well as its popularity among dog keepers in Munich, the dachshund was chosen to be the first officialmascotfor the1972 Summer Olympicsin Munich, with the nameWaldi.cite webhttp://www.swifterhigher.com/2008/07/meet-the-mascots-waldi-munich.phpMeet the Mascots: Waldi (Munich 1972)Whelliston, Kyle2008-07-08Swifter Higher2010-01-07http://web.archive.org/web/20100308075540/http://swifterhigher.com/2008/07/meet-the-mascots-waldi-munich.php 8 Mar 2010
article.heading: Sports
article.paragraph: File:Short haired dachshund in race.jpgthumbA short haired dachshund in organized raceSome people train and enter their dachshund to compete indachshund racingdachshund races, such as theWiener Nationals. Several races across the United States routinely draw several thousand attendees, including races inGermantown, Tennessee;Bossier City, Louisiana;Buda, Texas;Davis, California;Phoenix, Arizona;Los Alamitos, California;Findlay, Ohio;Milwaukee,Wisconsin;Oklahoma City,Oklahoma;Kansas City, Kansas;Palo Alto, California; andShakopee, Minnesota. There is also an annual dachshund run inKennywood, located inPittsburgh,Pennsylvania, called the Wiener 100, and inHuntington, West Virginiacalled the Dachshund Dash.

Despite the popularity of these events, the Dachshund Club of America opposes "wiener racing", as many greyhound tracks use the events to draw large crowds to their facilities. The DCA is also worried about potential injuries to dogs, due to their predisposition to back injuries. Another favorite sport isearthdog trials, in which dachshunds enter tunnels with dead ends and obstacles attempting to locate an artificial bait or live but caged and protected rats.cite webEarthdog Den TrialsCanada's Guide to Dogshttp://www.canadasguidetodogs.com/clubs/earthdog.htm2009-06-16
article.heading: DackelversusTeckel
article.paragraph: File:Mini-longhair-dachshund-puppy-24511277778995262f.jpgthumbDachshunds are popular with urban and apartment dwellersIn Germany, dachshunds are widely calledDackel(both singular and plural). Among hunters, they are mainly referred to asTeckel. There arekennelswhich specialize in breeding hunting dachshunds, the so-calledjagdliche Leistungszucht("hunting performance breed") orGebrauchshundezucht("working dog breed"), as opposed to breeding family dogs. Therefore, it is sometimes believed thatTeckelis either a name for the hunting breed or a mark for passing the test for a trained hunting dog (called "VGP", "Verband-Gebrauchsprfung") in Germany. It is not.FAQ of the German Teckelclub on the naming issue(in German)
article.heading: Popularity
article.paragraph:
Dachshunds are one of the most popular dogs in the United States, ranking 10th in the 2012 AKC registration statistics.cite webhttp://www.akc.org/news/the-most-popular-dog-breeds-in-america/AKC Dog Registration StatisticsAmerican Kennel ClubThey are popular with urban and apartment dwellers, ranking among the top ten most popular breeds in 76 of 190 major US cities surveyed by the AKC.cite webhttp://www.akc.org/register/top-dogs-by-city/2006 AKC Top Breeds By CityAmerican Kennel ClubOne will find varying degrees of organized local dachshund clubs in most major American cities, including New York, New Orleans, Portland, Los Angeles, and Chicago.-Image:Adolf Eberle Dackelfamilie.jpgthumbcenter
Die Dackelfamilie mit Jger und Magd(The Dachshund family with Hunter and maid) byAdolf Eberlethumbcenter
File:Jean-Baptiste Oudry - Hound with Gun and Dead Game - WGA16780.jpgthumbcenter
Jean-Baptiste Oudry- Dachshund with Gun and Dead Game, 1740File:L Riedler Hunde 1 Wie wird es enden.jpgthumbcenter
How will it end?Wie wird es enden?c. 1900.File:Dackel mit Bierkrug.jpgthumbcenter
German postcard with inscription "This beer belongs to my master!" c. 1900.
article.heading: Notable dogs and owners

list.listitem: Queen Victoriaowned a dachshund whom she called Dash, recorded in her diary in 1833, and received another dachshund from her husbandAlbert, Prince ConsortPrince Albertin 1845.Alfred Gingold (2005). "Dog World: And The Humans Who Live There". p. 231. Thornsike Press,Ann Gordon (2005). "Dachshund: Your Happy Healthy Pet". p.22. John Wiley & Sons,

John F. Kennedybought a dachshund puppy while touring Europe in 1937 for his then girlfriend Olivia. The puppy, named Dunker, never left Germany after Kennedy started to get terrible allergies.John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and MuseumJohn F. Kennedy with "Dunker" during tour of Europe in the summer of 1937, The Hague, August 1937.

Grover Cleveland, the 22nd and 24th President, had a dachshund in the White House.cite webWhite House Pets Menu 1850 to 1889http://www.presidentialpetmuseum.com/whitehousepets-3.htmPresidential Pet MuseumApril 30, 2011
William Randolph Hearstwas an avid lover of dachshunds. When his own dachshund Helena died, he eulogized her in his "In The News" column.Belozerskaya, MarinaThe Medici Giraffe(2006) 371.

Fred,E.B. White's dachshund, appeared in many of his famous essays.cite webLightness: E.B. White On Atomic Energyhttp://www.trufax.org/paradigm/paradigm/lightness.html3 Nov 2014http://web.archive.org/web/20060420135118/http://www.trufax.org/paradigm/paradigm/lightness.html20 Apr 2006

Lump (dog)Lump, the pet ofPablo Picasso, who was thought to have inspired some of his artwork. (Pronounced: loomp; German for "Rascal")Picasso & Lump: A Dachshund's Odysseytells the story of Picasso and Lump.

Jack Ruby, the killer ofLee Harvey Oswald, had a dachshund named Sheba, which he often referred to as his wife.At the time he committed his infamous murder, he had four of themalthough he once had as many as ten.Bugliosi, VincentReclaiming History: The Assassination of President John F. KennedyNorton. 2007 pg 8

Andy Warholhad a pair of dachshunds, Archie and Amos, whom he depicted in his paintings and mentioned frequently in his diaries.cite webhttp://dachshundlove.blogspot.com/2007/11/dachshunds-in-pop-culture-andy-warhol.htmlDachshunds in Pop Culture: Andy WarholDachshundlove.blogspot.com2007-11-172012-05-16

Stanley and Boodgie, immortalized on canvas by ownerDavid Hockney, and published in the bookDavid Hockney's Dog Days.cite webCollege ArchaeologyArt History HistoryRomehttp://www.thamesandhudsonusa.com/new/fall06/528627.htmDavid Hockney's Dog DaysThamesandhudsonusa.com2012-05-16

Wadl and Hexl,Wilhelm II, German EmperorKaiser Wilhelm II's famous ferocious pair. Upon arriving atArchdukeArchduke Franz Ferdinand of AustriaFranz Ferdinand's country seat,chteauKonopit, on a semi-official visit, they promptly proceeded to do away with one of theAustriaHungaryAustro-Hungarianheir presumptive's pricelessgolden pheasants, thereby almost causing an international incident.Another one of his beloved dachshunds, Senta, is currently buried atHuis Doorn, Wilhelm's manor in the Netherlands.cite newsPatersonTonyEnd of the line for Germany's Last EmperorThe Independent18 November 2012http://www.huisdoorn.nl/eng/25 January 2014

Former Secretary of DefenseDonald Rumsfeldwas asked, in 2003, whether he has duct tape, plastic sheeting, and a three-day supply of bottled water at home. He replied, "I would like to say I did. I don't believe we do. But I do have a miniature dachshund named Reggie who looks out for us."cite webhttp://www.newsweek.com/id/58708Newsweek Article ''Perspectives''Newsweek MagazineMarch 17, 20032009-06-16

InZelenogorsk, Saint PetersburgZelenogorsk,Russia, is a Dachshund monument near which passes a parade of Dachshunds on City Day, July 25.cite newshttp://www.fontanka.ru/2009/07/25/007/Zelenogorsk are celebrates 461st anniversary from the date of the basisru:Зеленогорск отмечает 461-ю годовщину со дня основания2009-07-25Society[http://www.fontanka.ru/ fontanka.ru]Russian

Joe was the dachshund of GeneralClaire Lee Chennault, commander of theFlying Tigersand then the China Air Task Force of theUS Army Air Forces, and became the mascot of those organizations.Robert Lee Scott, Jr.Scott, Robert L. Jr.,God Is My Co-Pilot (book)God Is My Co-Pilot(1943)

Maxie, a dachshund owned by actressMarie Prevost, tried to awaken his dead mistress, who was found with small bites on her legs. Maxie's barking eventually summoned neighbours to the scene. The incident inspired the 1977Nick Lowesong "Marie Prevost".cite bookGoldenEveKing, BobGolden Images: 41 Essays on Silent Film StarsMcFarland20011400-7864-0834-0

Liliane Kaufmann, wife ofEdgar J. Kaufmannwho commissioned the homeFallingwaterfrom Frank Lloyd Wright in 1935, was a well known breeder and owner of long-haired dachshunds. At the Fallingwater bookstore, visitors are able to purchase a book titled "Moxie" which is about one of the dachshunds who lived at Fallingwater.cite webhttp://www.fallingwater.org/120/moxie-the-dachshund-of-fallingwaterMoxie: The Dachshund of Fallingwater[[Fallingwater]]Mill Run, PA, USANovember 28, 2011Liliane raised long haired dachshunds and they travelled from Pittsburgh to Bear Run with her.citation neededNovember 2011

Obie is a dachshund who became infamous for his obesity, weighing as much asconvert77lbkgoff, more than twice a normal-weight standard dachshund.cite newsNora Vanattahttp://www.oregonlive.com/pets/index.ssf/2012/09/obese_dachshund_takes_on_chall.htmlObese Dachshund takes on challenge of being Doxie version of 'Biggest Loser'OregonLive.com2012-10-032012-09-07cite newshttp://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/09/10/obie-the-obese-dachshund_n_1871369.htmlObie The Obese Dachshund: One Adorable Doxie's Mission To Lose 40 Pounds (PHOTOS)Huffingtonpost.com2012-10-03SarahMedina2012-09-10He reached his target weight ofconvert28lbkgonin July 2013.cite webhttp://www.kgw.com/home/Obie-the-Dachshund-reaches-goal-weight-217785851.htmlObie the Dachshund reaches goal weightKGW.com28 April 2014JeffThompson
